snippet: A study by researchers at Stanford suggests that additional cancer-related deaths from radioactive materials released in last year’s accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be as low as 15 cases and as high as 1,300.
abstract: Study by researchers at Stanford suggests that additional cancer-related deaths from radioactive materials released in the 2011 accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be as low as 15 cases and as high as 1,300, a range that highlights the uncertainties associated with any attempts to predict the disaster’s health effects.
lead_paragraph: A study by researchers at Stanford suggests that additional cancer-related deaths from radioactive materials released in last year’s accident at the Fukushima Daiichi plant could be as low as 15 cases and as high as 1,300.

headline.main: Japan: Estimate of a Cancer Toll
headline.print_headline: Japan: Estimate of a Cancer Toll
